From the editorial page (SA Perspectives, Okay, We Give Up, p 10) of the new issue of Scientific American:
 
...this magazine's coverage of socalled evolution has been hideously one-sided. For decades, we published articles in every issue that endorsed the ideas of Charles Darwin and his cronies...Why were we so unwilling to suggest that dinosaurs lived 6,000 years ago or that a cataclysmic flood carved the Grand Canyon? Blame the scientists. They dazzled us with their fancy fossils, their radiocarbon dating and their tens of thousands of peer-reviewed journal articles. As editors, we had no business being persuaded by mountains of evidence.

 Further along in the article:
 
we shamefully mistreated the Intelligent Design (ID) theorists by lumping them in with creationists. Creationists believe that God designed all life, and that's a somewhat religious idea. But ID theorists think that at unspecified times some unnamed superpowerful entity designed life, or maybe just some species, or maybe just some of the stuff in cells. That's what makes ID a superior scientific theory: it doesn't get bogged down in details.

 And still more:
 
We owe it to our readers to present everybody's ideas equally and not to ignore or discredit theories simply because they lack scientifically credible arguments or facts. Nor should we succumb to the easy mistake of thinking that scientists understand their fields better than, say, U.S. senators or best-selling novelists do. Indeed, if politicians or special-interest groups say things that seem untrue or misleading, our duty as journalists is to quote them without comment or contradiction...In that spirit, we will end the practice of expressing our own views in this space: an editorial page is no place for opinions.

 And at last:
 
This magazine will be dedicated purely to science, fair and balanced science, and not just the science that scientists say is science.

I don't know, thebootfitter. The smilies that Hunter used seem to indicate that he understands the motivation behind the Scientific American article, and he is just doing more of the same. His whole post is scientifically illiterate idiocy. He is just carrying on in the spirit of the SA editorial.
 
 For example, he speaks of proof. We are all aware that such demands are made only by scientific illiterates. And the demand for proof is followed by the typical claptrap about leading people away from Jesus. Notice that there is no indication of what Jesus has to do with the question. Typical creationist clap-trap. Hunter was most certainly talking, tongue in cheek.
 
 And then there is the unstated implication that DNA evidence supports the fact that we all came from a single breeding pair. Again, Hunter is repeating claptrap meant to dupe the ignorant, no doubt in the spirit of the SA editorial. Since Hunter brought it up, I'm sure that he is perfectly aware that the most recent DNA evidence indicates that "Eve" (at 140,000 years ago) lived some 80,000 years before "Adam" (at 60,000 years ago). What we are talking about is our most recent common ancestor (MRCA) traced through mtDNA in the case of the mitochondrial Eve, and our MRCA traced through the X chromosome in the case of the X chromosome Adam. It probably wasn't a good idea to use the names from the Bible in this case, since creationists aren't scientifically literate enough to separate the use of the name from the scientific evidence. I think that this is what Hunter is pointing out.
 
 Of course, the link between "pond scum" and liberalism is another nonsense claim. No one in his right mind would make such a statement. I must say, Hunter has done an excellent job of giving us a parody of the ignorance of the creationist position. And that is followed by a reference to "love" as a gift from a magical being. We, of course, scratch our heads and wonder what the statement has to do with evolutionary theory.
 
 And of course, Hunter closes with the mandatory reference to what Darwin himself said, followed by an assertion that no transitionals have been found in spite of Darwin's prediction. I'm sure that Hunter is quite aware that in the 150 years since Darwin published his theory, there have been many, many transitionals found.
 
 It is quite clear that Hunter is just going along with the gag simply because he hasn't bothered to comment at all on the Archaeopteryx as a transitional thread. Clearly, Hunter accepts Archy as a transitional, as well as the transitional whale fossils and the well documented horse series.
 
 Hunter is just mocking the ignorance of creationists. Case closed.

Evolution is called a theory because it lacks the scientific proof to be called a fact. Okay then, who can argue with this simple truth?

 I wouldn't dream of arguing with the truth. However, your statement isn't it. Your statement demonstrates a profound ignorance and an unwillingness to learn. Attitudes like yours are typically the sign of weak faith. You see, your faith isn't strong enough to accept the universe as God created it, you have to rely on the 3000 year old mythology of nomadic herdsmen. I think that the reason is that such stories are so childish that they are easy for the ignorant to grasp. It certainly saves on learning anything about science, since science requires considerable effort to understand.
 
 For example, anyone who had made an honest effort to learn even the basics of what he claims to oppose would know that theories don't grow up to be facts. That's childish, but it is typical of creationists and "creation science." Creationists begin with the conclusions that they interpret from a literal reading of the mythology of the Bible. Most Christians are perfectly aware of the allegorical nature of much of the Bible - the two creation stories, the flood of Noah, and even the stories of Johah and Job - so ridiculous as history, but serving quite nicely as moral tales. But creationists, after they have decided on the answers, go in search of the questions. Creationists go from the conclusions to the facts by selective twisting and interpretation of the observation.
 
 So it is quite understandable that a creationist would believe that a scientific theory will grow up to be a fact. In actuality, the facts come first. Sometimes a certain combination of facts will suggest an idea to a scientist. They will express that as an hypothesis that is a possible explanation of the facts. This is the wild guess part of science and is one step beyond the operation of "creation science." But the hypothesis still doesn't advance science. First the scientist makes a prediction of further facts that must also be true if the hypothesis is correct. The next step is to design an experiment to test the prediction. If the hypothesis passes the test, in other words, if the predicted facts are observed, then the work is usually published for review by other scientists. When the hypothesis has been tested strongly enough and there is little doubt that it is correct, then it is called a theory. That is as good as it gets in science.
 
 A good example was Einstein's general theory of relativity. One prediction made by Einstein was that light would bend when passing through a strong gravitational field. But the technology to observe that prediction didn't exist for a long time. It was a number of years before it was observed during a total exlipse that a star whose light was passing very close to the sun appeared to be displaced closer to the sun. By that time, however, general relativity had been verified by many other experiments so that it was no longer in doubt. General relativity was a correction to Newton's theory of gravity.
 
 So Hunter. Please at least have the integrity to learn the basics of what you oppose. How else do you know that you oppose it if you don't even know what it is. Why be like most of the rest of the creationists of the world and let someone else do your thinking for you?

 You seem to be a bit slow. Of course evolution is a theory, besides being a fact. Gravity is a theory too, you know. How about the heliocentric theory, or do you claim that the earth is at the center of the universe? Atomic theory, nuclear theory, lots of theories.

 No. At one time it was an hypothesis. Then lots of observations, predictions and testing affirmed it so strongly that it is now regarded as a theory. Of course there are actually many theories of evolution.
 
Since you seem to be so intelligent, why is it that you are unaware of this widely known fact, to wit: DNA strictly prohibits the crossing of species and the theory that everything is evolving upward. This simple fact alone makes evolution impossible.

 Exactly how does DNA prohibit the crossing of species? The crossing of closely related species has been observed frequently. For example, horses and donkeys, or brown bears and polar bears. But both examples are of organisms that had common ancestors. Crossing species isn't part of evolutionary theory. Evolutionary theory is about what caused two populations of bear to separate into different species, like the brown bear and the polar bear. And there is no theory that everything is evolving upward that I know of. Does that mean that species are floating in the air or climbing mountains or what? It doesn't make sense. Whatever it means, it isn't part of the theory of evolution. You have been duped by someone who played upon your ignorance and lied to you. You don't know enough to recognize that.
 
Added to that is the fact that there have been no transitional fossils ever found.

Most aren't even aware that fundamentalist Christianity is little more than 100 years old.

 Well, it depends on what you call fundamentalism.
 If you consider Martin Luther's call to "get back to the basics" as fundamentalism then it's been around for almost 500 years.
 Then all those protestant groups split off with characters like John Calvin and Ulrich Zwingli.
 They all wanted the church to "return" to a more "pure" form.
 
 I think the type of fundamentalism that caught on in America was the brand espoused by Calvin and other puritans. This is the type of fundamentalism that we associate with the term "christian fundamentalists." And, Calvin was one of the first people to organize social structure along biblical lines. It was easy to start towns and cities that way in America because they were starting pretty much from scratch.
 
 So even this American brand of thinking and doing dates back about 400 years. Most of the first English settlers were of this Calvinist type protestantism. That's why we had the witch trials and the whole lot.
 
 Christian fundamentalism is at the heart of American culture (not solely).
 It'll be hard to shake if we can ever shake it at all.
pandion

Well, it depends on what you call fundamentalism.

 I call fundamentalism that particular christian cult that grew out of the milenarian movement at the end of the 19th Century. Fundamentalism was based on 5 fundamental tenets and espoused in the publishing of 12 pamphlets in the early 20th Century. That is the origin of the word. American fundamentalism is not based on the Puritans or on Calvin. Any other use is only by extension - for example Islamic fundamentalism or Calvinistic fundamentalism are secondary uses of the word. Apparently the use of the word has become so broad that it no longer has much meaning.
gnojek

I thought fundamentalism was a broad word that meant , well:
 
 http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=fundamentalism
 fun·da·men·tal·ism (fnd-mntl-zm)
 n.
 
 1. A usually religious movement or point of view characterized by a return to fundamental principles, by rigid adherence to those principles, and often by intolerance of other views and opposition to secularism.
 2.
 1. often Fundamentalism An organized, militant Evangelical movement originating in the United States in the late 19th and early 20th century in opposition to Protestant Liberalism and secularism, insisting on the inerrancy of Scripture.
 2. Adherence to the theology of this movement.

OK My mistake. I should have said Fundamentalist Christianity. Those 12 pamphlets were called "The Fundamentals", by the way, the source of the name. Anyway, a fundamentalist (sometimes fundy) is a Fundamentalist Christian. Could it be that you're not from the U.S.? That would certainly explain your unfamiliarity. One of the characteristics of Fundamentalism was its backlash against the expanding knowledge of the universe that was being discovered by science. Fundamentalism rejected new theories of astronomy, cosmology, geology, physics, and of course, biology. Fundamentalists are Biblical literalists, believing that every word of the Bible is both historically and scientifically true. Most fundamentalists will tell you that the universe was created 6,000 years ago and that there was a global flood about 4500 years ago, etc.
 
 And these are the people who are getting elected to school boards in Kansas and see no problem in teaching their religion in science class and making christian prayer a part of every school activity. And still they are able to maintain that they are good Americans. Fundamentalists are mostly responsible for the current assault against the freedoms of the Bill of Rights. All but the 2nd Amendment, which they insist gives them the right to own military assault weapons and to carry them freely.

pandion

When I see a Confederate flag I sometimes think of the Lord Jesus Christ and his twelve disciples

 That's funny. It's interesting that most people think that the Army Battle Flag or the Navy Jack are the flags of the Confederate States. I think I first realized that neither was the flag of the Confederate States when I saw a six flags over Texas display for the first time. None of the flags was the "Southern Cross." In looking into the matter, I found that the Stars and Bars was the first flag of the confederacy, followed by two others in 1863 and 1864 that did incorporate the southern cross as a canton. Most 6 flags displays use the Stars and Bars, but even that tends to draw protest when it is in a court room. The flag that most red necks display is the Navy Jack.

From the editorial page (SA Perspectives, Okay, We Give Up, p 10) of the new issue of Scientific American:
 
 Further along in the article:
 
 And still more:
 
 And at last:

 I don't think sicence and religion conflict. I think man's understanding of both conflict.
 
 God newver said he created this earth from nothing. He could have created it from material that already existed.
 
 Also God never said how long Adam and Eve were in the Garden. it could have been billions of years.
 
 All the time science admits that previous beliefs were wrong about numerous things. So how can people really eb confident they know either?
 
 There are a lot of unknown.
Mach

I don't think sicence and religion conflict. I think man's understanding of both conflict.
 
 God newver said he created this earth from nothing. He could have created it from material that already existed.
 
 Also God never said how long Adam and Eve were in the Garden. it could have been billions of years.
 
 All the time science admits that previous beliefs were wrong about numerous things. So how can people really eb confident they know either?
 
 There are a lot of unknown.

 
 Your fundamental misprepresentation of both science and religion is apalling.
 
 SCIENCE = KNOWLEDGE
 All knowledge is falsifiable, by definition.
 
 If knowledge was not falsifiable, it would be fiction.
 
 Here is your example Mana'ia:
 On the island of Hawaii, an old native Hawian spent his life researching the history of the island. He found numerous fragements of a man's bones and saw some markings that he thought, based on the evidence and his knowledge, it was an indication of murder (a hole in the skull). 15 years later, additional digs and research lead archaeologists to conclude these particular early hawians performed "trepanning", or removing a piece of the skull to "exorcise" demons and cure the patient. Re-examining the old skull fragments, the old man concludes that it was most likely a case of trepanning (comparing it to other samples and the physics of a blow vs meticulous chipping). He corrects his conclusion, based on the newest evidence.
 
 Then a little religious boy runs in and says "nananana, you don't know anything, you changed your mind *sticks tongue out* Har har.
 Kids.
 
 Enter religion.
 
 Religion is not falsifiable, it's dogmatic nonsense (rationally speaking), and is irrelevant to a discussion about what is correct, or incorrect.
 An example of religious dogma:
 
 God is real.
 
 OK, so...how can we show this to be false? You can't, that's why it's fictional dogma. Even with 0 evidence to support it, some people still think it's "true", which is why science (knowledge), is mututally exclusive with dogmatic, religious teachings (fiction).
 
 -Mach
mana'ia

Your fundamental misprepresentation of both science and religion is apalling.

 I said understanding and you characterized it as knowledge. Different but related terms.
Duo_Maxwell

There is evidence that God is real.

 
 That's a good one. No such evidence exists, hence why such beliefs are called faith, because they rest upon ideas without proof. If there WAS evidence, faith of such a God would not exist.

Duo_Maxwell

Eyewitnesses

 
 Illusions? Personal beliefs masking the truth? Dillusions? Insanity?
 
 HELLO. 
 
 
prophecies

 
 I asked this question in the religious section and got nothing.
 Name me a prophecy that can only be fulfilled by a single of historical event. 
 Good luck, you're not going to find one. Prophecies are written vaguely enough so that a number of events could fulfil them. Nostradum for example is so damn vague that almost anything can fufil what he says. 
 
 
and history are all evidence of His existence.

 
 Bull****. Cop out. Please, name me something that proves God exists. 
 
 

 Faith is not a perfect knowledge. You can have a partial knowledge and still have faith.

 
 Faith is not knowledge. Faith is a belief which rests upon the lack of proof and knowledge. IT is IMPOSSIBLE to have faith and knowledge of the same thing. 
 
 There is no proof of God. There cannot be. It is impossible for a very simple reason. God if it exists, is of the supernatural. How can the natural prove what is of another realm? It cannot.

Eyewitnesses, prophecies, and history are all evidence of His existence.

Eyewitnesses, prophecies, and history are all evidence of His existence.
 Faith is not a perfect knowledge. You can have a partial knowledge and still have faith.

 
 No they aren't Mana'ia. They don't fit the definition of being falsifiable in this case. They also contradict every single thing that is known about the way the universe functions, and thus, to actually disprove physics (science in general), you'd need both a theory, and proof, neither of which you, or ANYONE, has, or can have. Unless you can build us a time machine AND give us a logical explanation for your fantasies of "prohpecies", etc., you're stuck with good 'ole fashioned reality.
 
 Faith is NOT knowledge. Faith is belief WITHOUT evidence. Knowledge is a belief that is rationally justified by evidence. 
 
 If religion is used as a philosophy of life and society, fine, it doesnt NEED to be falsifiable. Most of our philosophies aren't, our ideals are generally not falsifiable either, yet they are important. Likewise religion isn't falsifiable, it's not knowledge, it says NOTHING about "reality", but it may indeed be important to you and many others. Just don't try to contradict reality in the process...please.
 
 And I quote:
 
All the time science admits that previous beliefs were wrong about numerous things. So how can people really eb confident they know either?

 
 Indeed, if science did NOT admit it was wrong, and CORRECT knowledge based on EVIDENCE, it would not be science, and it would not be falsifiable!!!!!!! 
 
 The only way we have confidence in ANY knowledge is through evidence, which faith does not require. Therefore, yes, we can have confidence in science, and yes, we cannot have confidence in faith-based declarations. Confidence has no meaning there, it's DOGMA, it cannot be false (or true).
 
 -Mach

 Matt 24
 1 AND Jesus went out, and departed from the temple: and his disciples came to him for to ashew him the buildings of the btemple.
 
 2 And Jesus said unto them, aSee ye not all these things? verily I say unto you, There shall not be left here one bstone upon another, that shall not be thrown down.
 
 As the attack against the Temple itself and the Jews who were guarding it, intensified, the building was seen to be burning. Some of the Roman soldiers spurred on by this ran in to the temple and began to set more fires. Titus by now had arrived on the scene and despite making strenuous efforts to get his troops to quench the fires, the flames spread rapidly throughout the entire building. By now his soldiers were consumed with hate and greed and even though they could clearly hear Titus calling to them at the top of his voice, they paid no attention. In the end the entire temple was burned to the ground. One story tells of the Roman soldiers returning to the ruins when the fires had died out and actually pulling apart the blocks of masonry which had made up the walls and foundations in order to get the gold that had run in between the stonework. As well as the contents of the city of Jerusalem undoubtedly everything within the temple was also looted. It should not be overlooked that this was an exceptionally bloody episode by any historical standard. Accounts speak of over one million people being mercilessly slaughtered.

 I also happen to have an email from Mr. Hovind in which he declares that he does not copyright his material and in which he grants me explicit permission to distribute any of his materials, both in transcript and video form.
 
 Sadly, these videos aren't available on line any more. I'm glad I got them when I did. He also had transcripts available at one time, but those were withdrawn before the videos.
